Award.AwardTitle: RUI: New Applications of Curvature in Image Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator, students, and collaborators will develop and establish the mathematical foundations of new models for image processing, implement, test and compare these new models with existing ones, and directly apply these models to problems in image fusion, medical imaging, and video processing. The proposed work has several over-arching goals. The first is the development and mathematical analyses of a new framework for image denoising that exploits the rich information of the curvature of an image in a new and effective way. The second is a better understanding of how to model geometric features in learned, structured, and overcomplete dictionaries for processing and fusing degraded data. The new models proposed in this work will be formulated in both the variational and patch-based frameworks, and will mainly address data that have been compromised by noise and linear degradations.

Digital images are now used in almost every area of science and technology. The models developed in this project will be used to solve real world problems, including problems in image fusion, video processing, and medical imaging. However, the models will be formulated in enough generality to potentially be applied to a wide array of applications in the sciences. Software developed under the auspices of this grant will be made publicly available. This project will also support undergraduate researchers who will implement, test and compare new and existing image processing models, determine appropriate numerical schemes, work directly with scientists to apply these models to real world problems, and present their results at local and national meetings. The investigator regularly teaches courses on image processing, and leads workshops on image processing for middle school students and high school women and minorities. Thus this work will be applied to problems in the sciences, be accessible for others working in directly and indirectly related fields, promote the training of young scientists, and provide educational opportunities for underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Analyzing and processing digital images continues to be an essential issue in almost all fields of scientific research. Even with the latest technology, images still experience a level of degradation during formation, transmission and storage. Furthermore, acquiring images that have all desirable features is also still quite challenging, so a sequence of images may be required to obtain all necessary information. Thus the development of tools that are accurate, efficient, and mathematically sound is still a major challenge for the image processing community.

 The boundaries of objects within an image are some of the most important information to be retained and enhanced when automatically processing image data. The geometry of the curves comprising these object boundaries has proven to be a critical tool in the development of mathematically sound models for image processing. In this project we developed a new general framework for processing images by processing some geometric measure of the image data, including their level line curvature image and moving frame components. This approach is leading to a better understanding of novel ways in which the geometry of image can be both understood and exploited to break the optimal denoising bounds established for current state of the art techniques for processing a noisy image directly. We are also continuing to understand how various Besov seminorms can preserve piecewise smooth and textured image information. These approaches use information that include and go beyond object edge information, which is most commonly used, and preserve details better than the state of the art methods that exploit image self similarity. We also have developed mathematical models for fusing image data using sparse image representations. This is particularly helpful for obtaining a single image that contains all relevant image information from several images that have each undergone degradations, including noise, blur and pixel loss. All of these topics raise some interesting and important mathematical questions, provide a better understanding of the mathematical denoising/decomposition/image fusion framework, and have the potential to better recover important information from image data arising in a wide array of scientific fields, from medical imaging to geospatial image data.
